No. Entropy is defined for a system in a particular macroscopic state as Boltzmann’s constant times the logarithm of the number of microscopic configurations (quantum states) consistent with that macroscopic state, S=kBln(Ω)S=kBln⁡(Ω). Either the macroscopic state is not possible (Ω=0)(Ω=0), in which case the entropy is undefined, or there is at least one possible quantum state consistent with the macroscopic state (Ω≥1)(Ω≥1), in which case the entropy is zero or greater (S≥0)(S≥0).

Yes it can be. Any process in which the randomness of the final state is less than the randomness of the initial state will result in a lowering of entropy. A few examples are, adsorption of gasses or aqueous ions on a solid, combination reaction like formation of NaCl from sodium and chloride ions, and also crystallization, etc… Since entropy change is negative, according to the equation, ∆G= ∆H - T∆S The spontaneity of the reaction will reduce. Because ∆G will be less negative. But if the enthalpy change, ∆H is more negative compared to the magnitude of entropy change then the reaction still remains spontaneous.

Hello Debanjan… Entropy generation can’t be negative but change in entropy can be negative. We are not able to calculate entropy, we can calculate change in entropy with some reference point. So, when entropy of system decreases, change in entropy can be negative. :)
You cannot extract such amount of disorderly energy / randomness from a system to make its entropy negative. Its just not possible both experimentally and theoretically.
